curve.name: central sulcus
curve.start: at the superior end, next to interhemispheric fissure
curve.stop: at or near sylvian fissure
curve.notes: there are 3 parallel sulci, running supero-posterior to infero-anterior on the lateral surface of the brain; the middle one is the central sulcus; usually a continuous sulcus.

curve.name: precentral sulcus
curve.start: at superior end, close to interhemispheric fissure
curve.stop: at or near sylvian fissure
curve.notes: is parallel to central sulcus and anterior to it; is often interupted into 2 or more segments

curve.name: superior frontal sulcus
curve.start: posterior, at or near the superior sector of the precentral sulcus
curve.stop: close to the frontal pole
curve.notes: classically the SFS starts at the precentral sulcus, but it can actually run posteriorly past the precentral sulcus and reach the central sulcus; however,the beginning of the sulcus should not be trace inside the precentral gyrus, it should start at the level of the precentral sulcus; most often this sulcus is interupted at more than one place, it is really a conjunction of several short sulci running postero-anteriorly parallel to the long axis of the hemisphere.

curve.name: inferior frontal sulcus
curve.start: posteriorly at the inferior sector of the precentral sulcus
curve.stop: before reaching the frontal pole
curve.notes: usually starts at the precentral sulcus; can, on occasion continue posteriorly past the precentral sulcus, but this happens less often then with the SFS; may also not completely reach the precentral sulcus; can be continuous or have multiple segments; tends to curve downward at the anterior end close to the pole; should extend inferiorly to the horizontal branch of the sylvian fissure

curve.name: ascending branch of the sylvian fissure
curve.start: inferiorly, at the anterior end of the sylvian fissure
curve.stop: at its superior end, close to the IFS
curve.notes: almost a vertical sulcus running anterior to the inferior segment of the precentral sulcus and parallel to it

curve.name: horizontal branch of the sylvian fissure
curve.start: at the anterior end of the sylvian fissure, often together with the ascending branch
curve.stop: before reaching the anterior segment of the IFS
curve.notes: very often this mostly horizontal sulcus starts together with the ascending branch forming a V with a more horizontal anterior arm; can also be separate from the ascending branch and start close but in front of it; or, can actually take of from a common stem with the ascending branch

curve.name: lateral orbital sulcus
curve.start: anterior to the origin of the horizontal branch and inferior to it
curve.stop: close to the pole

curve.name: frontomarginal sulcus
curve.start: close to the midline
curve.stop: on the lateral surface close to the pole
curve.notes: a relatively small sulcus seen best in a frontal view of the brain

curve.name: cingulate sulcus
curve.start: antero-inferior end, inferior to the beek of the corpus callosum
curve.stop: at the level of the interhemispheric fissure
curve.notes: the cings rouns parallel to the corpus callosum; shortly after the mid-point of the corpus callosum it inflects, more or less abruptly, upwards to reach the interhemispheric fissure; this posterior section, called the ascending branch of the cinS is a good landmark to identify the mesial extension of the central sulcus which appears just anterior to it; the cingS is often interupted into two or more segments; the cingS can also have a more or less complete parallel sulcus

curve.name: paracentral sulcus
curve.start: cingulate sulcus
curve.notes: small vertical sulcus that may be a side branch of the cingS

curve.name: supra orbital sulcus
curve.start: close to the posterior end of the of the ventro-mesial surface of the frontal lobe
curve.stop: close to the mesial aspect of the frontal pole
curve.notes: horizontal sulcus with postero-anterior direction, parallel to subcallosal sector of the cingS

curve.name: olfactory or medial orbital sulcus
curve.start: on the orbital surface of the frontal lobe, close to its posterior end
curve.stop: before reaching the frontal pole
curve.notes: straight sulcus running almost parallel to interhemispheric fissure

curve.name: superior temporal sulcus with upper branch
curve.start: close to the temporal pole
curve.stop: at the posterior end of the temporal lobe
curve.notes: the STS is most often a continuous single sulcus, but it can have true interruptions; it usually splits into 2 diverging branches, close to the end of the temporal lobe; the superior branch may turn upwards an run into the parietal lobe; the inferior branch may turn downward an continue into the occipital lobe; on occasion there can be a 3 way split

curve.name: inferior temporal sulcus
curve.start: below the STS at the level of the anterior end
curve.stop: at the posterior end of the temporal lobe
curve.notes: the ITS is often difficult to identify; it is often subdivided into several segments

curve.name: occipito temporal sulcus
curve.start: close to the temporal pole
curve.stop: at the level of the posterior end of the collateral sulcus
curve.notes: the temporal occipital sulcus is often difficult to identify; it is seen on the inferior surface of the temporal lobe, and runs laterally and parallel to the collateral sulcus

curve.name: collateral sulcus
curve.notes: the most medial of the temporal sulci; best seen in an incomplete inferior view; abuts anteriorly at the rhinal sulcus, which is immediately in front of the uncus; is usually continuous without interuptions; ends often as a single sulcus runnig into the occipital lobe where it forms the lower lateral border of the lingual gyrus; ends as often in a split of two terminal rami of variable length

curve.name: transverse temporal sulcus
curve.notes: not seen from the outer view of the brain; runs posteromedially to antero-laterally in on the superior surface of the superior temporal gyrus; in order to see it clearly the frontal and parietal lobes need to be removed; here, looking into the space between the temporal lobe below and the parietal operculum above, the sulcus can be seen; can be double, in this case take the more anterior one

curve.name: circular sulcus
curve.start: most anterior and inferior point in axial slices
curve.direction: first up, then posteriorly, and finally inferiorly
curve.stop: most inferior and anterior in coronal slices stopping just before reaching the initial point
curve.notes: the circulaar sulcus creates the limit of the insula; it cannot be seen from the external view of the hemisphere; best traced on a combination of axial and coronal slices

curve.name: postcentral sulcus
curve.start: interhemisphereic fissure
curve.stop: at the sylvian fissure
curve.notes: the postcentral sulcus is the 3rd, and more posterior of the 3 parallel sulci seen on the lateral surface of the hemisphere; it is quite often interupted into two or more segments; on occasion it can be double

curve.name: intraparietal sulcus
curve.start: at the postcentral culcus, close to the middle
curve.stop: at the end of the parietal lobe when it abbuts the transverse temporal sulcus
curve.notes: clearly identifiable as a long, usually continuous sulcus, more or less parallel to the interhemisphereric fissure; can, at the anterior end bend laterally and reach the postcentral sulcus a bit lower then the mid point; can, on occasion have true interuptions; can cross the postcentral sulcus and divide the post central gyrus

curve.name: occipito parietal sulcus
curve.start: junction with the calcarine sulcus
curve.stop: interhemispheric fissure
curve.notes: clearly marked sulcus; very rarely interupted; superior end may have a short byfurcation

curve.name: subparietal sulcus
curve.start: at the posterior end of the cingS
curve.stop: behind the splenium of the corpus callosum
curve.notes: could be considered the continuation of the cingS, but may start a few millimeters behind the cingS at the level where this sulcus bends upward; is rarely a continuous sulcus delineating the posterior sector of the cingulate gyrus; most often a conjunction of small short sulci

curve.name: calcarine sulcus
curve.start: juncture with parieto occipital sulcus
curve.stop: occipital pole
curve.notes: clearly identifiable sulcus running antero-posteriorly, often with a curvature with concavity facing down; can have interuptions on occasion; can terminate in T or as a single branch; can run into the outer surface of the hemisphere

curve.name: transverse occipital sulcus
curve.start: close to interhemispheric fissure
curve.stop: natural end
curve.notes: this is a transverse sulcus on the dorsolateral and posterior aspect of the brain; it sits at the posterior end of the intraparietal sulcus

curve.name: lateral occipital sulcus
curve.start: close to lateral end of the transverse occipital sulcus
curve.stop: at the temporl occipital junction
curve.notes: this is a longitudinal sulcus dividing the lateral surface of the occipital lobe into a superior and inferior sector, mostly ontinuous
